captions.text:
As my wife will tell you, I love disappointing 
people. Best to enjoy the things you&#39;re good at,

after all. I particularly love when 
indie game developers come to me saying,

&quot;Look at this completely original idea we&#39;ve come 
up with&quot; because I can take one look at it and go,

&quot;Oh, that&#39;s not original; that&#39;s just 
Stardew Valley crossed with XCOM crossed

with Custer&#39;s Revenge or whatever. Better 
luck next time.&quot; Watching the light go out

of their little eyes as I talk, it&#39;s 
basically the only way I can come,

these days. Almost makes it worth wasting my 
life playing thousands of shitty video games

during the best years of my hairline. That&#39;s 
why it&#39;s always noteworthy to find something

that utterly defies comparison. It happens so 
increasingly rarely. Especially these days,

now most of the new indie games are &quot;such 
and such meets Balatro, meets anime tits.&quot;

Katamari Damacy. Papers, Please. There weren&#39;t 
anything like those. In video games, at least,

respectively, they were comparable to making 
really efficient use of a brand new lint roller

and working a data validation job at a wonky 
desk perched on the lip of a woodchipping device.

And now there&#39;s Blue Prince, another of those 
very rare camel platypus tarantula hybrids that

defy comparison and terrify the absolute shit 
out of zoogoing schoolchildren. Where to start?

It&#39;s a first-person roguelike puzzle game with 
resource management elements. &quot;Is it possible

you oversold this, Yahtz?&quot; Shut the fuck up; 
I&#39;m still thinking about it. The premise is,

you are a 14-year-old snot with no friends or 
ambition in life and probably a track record

of rampant delinquency judging by the way 
you apparently don&#39;t have to go to school,

and after your eccentric great uncle dies, 
you inherit a massive great fuck-off house

to illustrate the complete absence of justice in 
this rudderless so-called society. But once the

paperwork&#39;s signed and you&#39;re gazing up at our 
new estate, the lawyer rolls down the window of

their already-started car and yells, &quot;Oh, by 
the way, you don&#39;t get to keep it unless you

find the secret room, and you&#39;re not allowed 
to sleep inside the mansion because all the

rooms change overnight and you&#39;ll presumably 
get horribly mashed up in the workings like

a cherry tomato in a garlic press. Bye, 
then! I set up a tent out by the bins!&quot;

Yes, when I said your great uncle was 
eccentric, he absolutely wasn&#39;t fucking

about. All his peers settled for collecting 
their piss in jars and being incredibly racist,

but not him; he was going for the full-on Sarah 
Winchester meets Wallace and Gromit. The rub is,

every day the house is rebuilt anew. 
It&#39;s set up on a perfectly square grid,

and every time you open a door, you have to pick 
what room lies beyond from three options, and very

few rooms have doors on all four walls, so you&#39;re 
building yourself a new mini-labyrinth every day,

where it&#39;s very possible to box yourself in and 
run out of ways to go if you&#39;re not savvy about

it. It soon becomes clear that finding that secret 
room is gonna take a hell of a lot more work than

finding the one suspiciously extruding book in 
the library. With the really on-the-nose title

like &quot;A Pictorial History of the US Open,&quot; or &quot;The 
Art of Very Obvious Hidden Room Construction by

U. R. Athicktwat.&quot; The secret room is deep in 
the heart of the mansion, and it&#39;s only going

to open after you&#39;ve followed a spiderweb of 
multiple threads of logic and puzzle-solving,

some of which lead to progress, some 
to new ways to improve your resources,

some to the hidden secrets at the heart of your 
family, and some might exist entirely in your

own mind like the nine-breasted snake woman that 
keeps telling me to set fire to the garden shed.

For example, at one point, I discovered that 
I can exit to the west side of the house if

I build a garage, and I became convinced that 
if I built one in the northwesternmost corner,

I could access the back of the house, where 
presumably could be found the money tree

and the prostitute conservatory and the one 
book that explains the entire fucking plot.

Fortunately, I was set right when I had a 
note-comparing session with my colleagues,

which was both helpful and terribly amusing to 
learn what deranged conspiracy theories they&#39;d

formulated. Their absolute certainty that there 
had to be something significant about the symbol

on two of the clock faces in the den. Or that 
smug, knowing look on the face of a taxidermied

robin in the lobby. Thing is, I&#39;m not even sure 
they&#39;re wrong. It&#39;s that kind of game. You build

the breakfast nook room on the promise of getting 
a free key and realize that the sequence of colors

on the wallpaper relates to the order you have 
to press the 11 colored nipples on the statue

of Shub-Niggurath in the forsaken temple room. 
So, the question surrounding any puzzle game is,

what specific mental skills does Blue Prince call 
upon, where Obra Dinn was about deduction and

elimination and The Witness was about repressing 
your urge to call Jonathan Blow a pretentious git?

Well, take your fucking pick. There&#39;s your 
resource management and learning most optimal room

placement, pattern recognition, the parlor has 
a new deductive logic puzzle to solve every day,

the billiard room has a darts-based number puzzle 
that starts off just having you add up the lit up

parts of the board and 40 days later is having 
you convert a number to two significant figures,

reverse the digits, divide by 12, and sacrifice 
a dog. Ultimately, though, the main mental skill

the game tests is your ability to not throw your 
chair through the screen because you got fucked

over by random chance for the 50th fucking 
time. Which is a point against Blue Prince,

I&#39;m afraid. I&#39;ve just about finished the game, 
but there&#39;s one last loose end that I can&#39;t tie up

until I build a house where a boiler room connects 
to a pump room, neither of which are guarantees,

and imagine my annoyance day after day, opening 
the one remaining door that a boiler room could

possibly go and randomly drawing Bunk room, 
Conservatory, Sex Dungeon. FUCK ME. NO,

NOT LITERALLY. Start again. I suppose the 
game wouldn&#39;t have that absorbing &quot;just one

more day&quot; quality if we weren&#39;t rubbing up 
against a certain amount of random chance.

That&#39;s how they get you, isn&#39;t it? You don&#39;t 
keep pulling on a slot machine lever because

it&#39;s good elbow exercise. Little bit scummy, 
yes, but it&#39;s a little bit scummy to make

me perform sexual favors by bribing me with 
chocolate. I&#39;ll feel dirty while I&#39;m doing it,

but I still get some tasty chocolate afterwards. 
What the fuck am I on about? The randomness is a

lot less frustrating when you do still have 
multiple loose ends you can be pursuing,

and at the end of the day, I can definitely 
recommend Blue Prince if you like reassuring

yourself of your own cleverness and some lovely 
immersion storytelling bubbling away behind the

scenes like a vat of boiling water brought in 
for an extremely ill-advised escapology show.

And again, its uniqueness alone makes it worth a 
look. If I had to compare it to something other

than another video game as I did earlier, I&#39;d say 
it&#39;s like filling out a puzzle page after someone

crafted it into an extremely complicated origami 
swan. And every few minutes, you roll the dice on

whether you hold the pen in your left hand, your 
right hand, or up your nostril. It&#39;s satisfying

to think about what I&#39;m eventually going to 
do to the asshole who fucked up my newspaper.
